head.title: Some Great Web Sites About the Great Lakes

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: Some Great Web Sites About the Great Lakes

abstract.p: Web site of Great Lakes Information Network provides excellent collection of information; map (S)

block.p: The Web site of the Great Lakes Information Network (www.glin.net) provides an excellent collection of information.
There is a site for the Great Lakes Circle Tour, for instance, which is a 6,500-mile trail around the lakes and the St. Lawrence Seaway.
The Web site of the Great Lakes Information Network (www.glin.net) provides an excellent collection of information.
There is a site for the Great Lakes Circle Tour, for instance, which is a 6,500-mile trail around the lakes and the St. Lawrence Seaway.
There is a system profile (Lake Superior, at 1,330 feet, is the deepest) and information on nuisance species like the zebra mussel, as well as history and cultural information.
Browser A selection of events and sites on the Web.
www.king-raleigh.org/natlevent/body.cfm A listing of events, searchable by state, honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the civil rights movement.

www.lpb.org/programs/forest/calculator.html A calculator for carbon debt, that is, the amount of carbon dioxide a household produces through household energy use, cars, household waste disposal and mass transit use.
www.dur.ac.uk/dla0www/c_tour/intro.html An online tour of Durham Castle and Cathedral, which overlook the river Wear in England. Construction of the castle began in 1072 under William the Conqueror.
carpoint.msn.com/autoshow2001/home.asp For car freaks, all the fast and shiny new models can be seen at the official site for the North American International Auto Show.
TODAY, 7 p.m. www.amuzenet.com A chat with members of Collective Soul, the rock band.
TUESDAY, 4 p.m. www.foodandwine.com A chat with Steve Jenkins, an expert on cheese.
TUESDAY, 8 p.m. www.healthatoz.com A chat about nutrition, with Elizabeth Somer, the author of ''The Origin Diet: How Eating Like Our Stone Age Ancestors Will Maximize Your Health.''
